posts.name: Ari Meles-Braverman
posts.cooked:
So I follow AndyMark on Facebook and noticed they posted this tip yesterday:

https://scontent.fsdv2-1.fna.fbcdn.net/v/t1.0-9/148333317_10158088544493230_412601111213357386_o.jpg?_nc_cat=101&ccb=3&_nc_sid=2c4854&_nc_ohc=fJM8XBBmv54AX8pXiBi&_nc_ht=scontent.fsdv2-1.fna&oh=7ab1ab40b311541935553f3fd2b82deb&oe=6048502F

The thing is, I always heard you should tighten bolts in diametrical pairs to get the most even preload. Something like this:

Clearly either way is better than tightening consecutive bolts in a circular patter. But I‚Äôm interested to hear whether other people learned the way I did or the way AndyMark suggests.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.custom_user_title: FIRST Israel CSA, FRC 5987/5951 Technical Mentor

posts.name: Carlos Gross Jones
posts.cooked: They‚Äôre not that much different. The goal is the same in either case, to distribute the pressure. I‚Äôd say that Andymark‚Äôs version is better than your middle figure, because it‚Äôs endlessly repeatable: if you try to do two rounds of tightening with the middle picture, you end up going 6 -> 1, which is not ideal.

user_custom_fields.user_field_4: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.custom_user_title: Mere hours of work can save you entire minutes of planning

posts.name: JamesCH95
posts.cooked:
image 1063√ó377 51.1 KB

image 1063√ó377 51.1 KB

image 1063√ó377 51.1 KB

I‚Äôm 99% sure this is what‚Äôs in my Bosch automotive handbook, but that‚Äôs at work and I‚Äôm in sweatpants and excruciatingly lazy.

Also, I‚Äôd be surprised if the tightening order mattered at all if the fasteners don‚Äôt have centering features like lug nuts do.

posts.name: Jim Forbes
posts.cooked:
somehow your picture didn‚Äôt show up on my screen‚Ä¶but I clicked it and did finally see it.

bolts 1200√ó628 92.7 KB

bolts 1200√ó628 92.7 KB

bolts 1200√ó628 92.7 KB

Thinking about the order that you tighten the screws, is usually the important thing here. The exact order isn‚Äôt that critical, as long as you draw the parts together evenly, and get parts snugged together before you get any fasteners really tight.

posts.name: wgorgen
posts.cooked:
I would add that progressive tightening is better than going all the way on the first pass.

On the first pass, you get them seated, but not torqued. On the second pass, you torque them moderately tight and then a final pass to final torque.

posts.name: Jim Forbes
posts.cooked:
And on Fords, you can indeed install the gasket the wrong way.

So be careful with Ford powered robots

posts.name: FrankJ
posts.cooked: The Volvo red blocks use stretch head bolts so they are single use. The iron block with Al heads really don‚Äôt like overheating regardless of the torquing order. So don‚Äôt do that either.

posts.name: Jim Forbes
posts.cooked: the only red block I rebuilt (from the 1960s) got it‚Äôs head bolts re used, they were not torque to yield back then.

posts.name: 829 The Digital Goats Official Curmudgeon.
posts.cooked: I always used studs instead of bolts for AI heads.

posts.name: Jim Forbes
posts.cooked: I have two hot rods with aluminum heads‚Ä¶both use bolts, don‚Äôt seem to have any problems with them. A 426 Hemi and a 427 Rat.

posts.name: Mr V
posts.cooked: The pattern shown by AM is what I learned to use on GM 1/2 ton 4x4s many decades ago and is how I‚Äôve been doing 6 bolts in a circular pattern ever since.

posts.name: Rod
posts.cooked: Always start by snugging up -all- the bolts finger tight‚Ä¶  Then gentle torque in a star pattern.  Real torque in a star pattern.  If you are heading off into 100+ ft-lbs territory and you‚Äôve deployed the torque multiplier or the hydraulic torque wrench then you can go to  round and round.  Of course, this is mostly important when you are working on stuff where the bolt set weighs more than a FRC robot Not crushing the gasket on one side and then cracking the flange is, as we like to say in the engineering world, ‚Äúgood‚Äù. That said, super nuts are really nice to work with!  Much better than getting out the BIG tools!

posts.name: Gus Michel II
posts.cooked:
My first experience with a bolt tightening pattern was in middle school, where I played snare drum in the marching band.  My drum had eight pegs, and I was taught (in addition to the several stages) to turn one peg, then move three to the right, then three more, etc.  As 3 and 8 are mutually prime, it worked great.  My next was changing a tire (five lugs), so I went two to the right each step.  I didn‚Äôt realize until changing my first six lug tire that a number can be TOO composite.  What I wound up doing (do on robot hubs) is to go to the right 2, 2, 3, 2, 2, 3.

The old AMC & Jeep straight six head follows a ‚Äúspiral out‚Äù pattern.  My dad had one, my mom had two, one of which I drove my college years, I had another 1990-2015, and now @Perebear has one under reconstruction in the driveway.

posts.name: RedLeader342
posts.cooked: i always diagonal when i do stuff like this. so like # 6 would actually be the 4th one i do. 5 would still be 5. 4 would be 6. and so on. but realistically its all the same

posts.name: MikLast
posts.cooked:
RedLeader342:

nascar proves every weekend its not that big of a deal.

NASCAR also goes for speed compared to the way longer time the FRC team has to tighten stuff down. Those components also last a fraction of the time compared to a FRC bot (or something where its actually life or death, like your own car.) The air guns they use also probably help in some way, even if the main goal is speed.

nascar is also moving to 1 lugnut next year so its gonna be moot either way

posts.name: RedLeader342
posts.cooked: Oh yeah for sure, the guns we used were so heavily engineered inside and out. Like 100‚Äôs of thousands of dollars of research. They could put those lugs on with 100+ ftlbs of tourque. It was mostly a joke but the background point to it was, its not really a big deal for these little wheels we use. As long as it all goes together straight. However it is definitely a good habit to teach, to follow proper torquing patterns
